Posts.Title: 5 years this week! marianleah Nanda

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 03:26AM sue_m wrote: Hi Grandma and welcome, I haven’t posted here very often but I have learned a lot here. So I just wanted to say welcome. I wish I had known about this forum when I was first diagnosed because it is very intimidating to get your diagnosis and then have to start reading all this stuff. Especially when you are Stage III. Certainly at first, none of it sounds as though the word “positive” could even belong on the same page, but as time goes on we get better at interpreting all these new facts and figures, and putting it all in perspective. This month is the 4th anniversary of when I discovered my lump so I identify with where you are today. Once treatment starts, life sort of moves along day by day and things seem less overwhelming. You’ve come to the right place,
Posts.Title: Newcomer of Breast Cancer at stage III JoyMia7 apple

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 06:47AM sue_m wrote: Hi Passenger, I had additional lymph nodes removed after my mastectomy. On a CT scan that was done about 8 weeks after the mastectomy and prior to starting chemo, something showed up in the axilla, so the onc wanted to go after more nodes. I expected the lymph node procedure to be easier than the mastectomy since it was day surgery. It was easier. I kept a rolled up towel against my side to keep my arm from pressing on it and I had no pain to speak of. They gave me a prescription for Vicodin but I didn’t need it. However, several days later I got an infection. Before the mastectomy, the surgeon had warned about the possibility of a seroma, but once the mastectomy was done I had pushed this out of my mind, so the whole infection thing came as a surprise. This kind of experience is the in the minority. Sometimes these things come up but we get through them. You’re right—it’s one day at a time! I feel that it was 100% worth it to go after the extra nodes. Good luck,
Posts.Title: more surgery Passenger59 sue_m

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2008 08:03PM sue_m wrote: Congratulations--Awesome! I am a lurker but I finally registered--might as well be counted while I'm still with NED. There is so much wisdom and support here. Each piece of good news stokes our hopes. Thanks so much for your post.
Posts.Title: 5 years this week. Carmelle sue_m

Posts.Content: May 4, 2008 04:18PM sue_m wrote: The stages are scary to read about at first. Likewise the pathology terms. I was diagnosed IIA at first and then changed to IIIA a couple of months after my mastectomy, after closer examination and removal of more lymph nodes. From what I understand, the main purpose of staging is to help the doctors determine the treatment plan, but the extra effect is that it scares us. I think at the outset it is helpful to know what we’re up against, i.e. how aggressive it is, and it gets less scary after a while as we get more familiar with all this stuff. (The education we didn’t sign up for.) Reading the posts here helps a lot. Best,

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 12:40AM sue_m wrote: Hi bcs75, Sorry I left it unclear about the number of treatments. I had 4 treatments A/C and 4 of Taxol, a week off after each. The 3rd A/C was the worst, the effects lasted into the following week, fatigue especially. I don't remember being so wiped out after the 4th A/C--and of course the fact that the 4th was going to be the last A/C was a big psychological boost. Hang in there, it will get better,
Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: May 11, 2008 08:34PM sue_m wrote: Hi Kalyla, I felt that the 3rd A/C was the worst of all of my chemo sessions. I had Taxol after A/C, and found it much easier. Aside from aches & pains the day after and being a little feverish for a couple of days, it was a lot easier than the A/C. Sorry to hear about the surgery. Hope the surgical aftereffects are going away. Before I had chemo I had an infection after lymph-node surgery and it took a while for that to clear up. Good luck,
